channel.title: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?
channel.description:
Alright, i'm going to do a bare-minimum upgrade of cpu, motherboard and memory. The plan is something along the lines of a 3.2ghz i7, 12gb ram and an appropriate motherboard for a reasonable price. My budget is basically infinite, but realistically i don't feel like spending over 1k euros.
Gogo suggestions!

item.title: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I don’t know what $2000 CPU you could buy that isn’t noticeably slower than a $200 one, unless you don’t do anything CPU bound ever…

Read full topic
item.source: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?

item.source: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?

item.title: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:17, topic:395974”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=493154.msg3606425#msg3606425 date=1306164782]
For the money, I think AMD processors are superior right now, you might want to look into them instead.
[/quote]My focus is top of the line performance, that’s why i’m choosing Intel. I’m using AMD as we speak, and i purchased it because i didn’t have a lot of money to burn at the time (and it works great). For my next upgrade however, i want to stay on top.[/quote]
It just depends how much you want to spend. You can spend $2000 on a CPU that will be a $400 CPU 3 months from now, so unless you have a lot of money you just want to throw away, you have to draw the line somewhere. I’d rather have a ~$200 CPU that isn’t the absolute top of the line, but isn’t noticeably slower than it either, and will still last for years.

Read full topic
item.source: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?

item.title: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

Moparisthebest:

For the money, I think AMD processors are superior right now, you might want to look into them instead.

AMD doesn’t support triple channel RAM, so that’s an instant downgrade right there.

Read full topic

I’m using AMD as we speak, and i purchased it because i didn’t have a lot of money to burn at the time (and it works great). For my next upgrade however, i want to stay on top.

item.title: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

I completely agree. But why buy a platform that is coming on to three years old and not just wait a few more months for the upgraded version of it?

Read full topic
item.source: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?

item.title: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?
item.dc:creator: @teh_spede Teh Spede
item.description:
@teh_spede wrote:

[quote=“tL, post:9, topic:395974”]I know what I’m about to do is sometimes frowned upon, but think about waiting for the successor to that platform (x58). It is pretty much the only platform Intel haven’t upgraded, it is their high end consumer chipset - so all they’ve been doing with it are these ridiculously priced 6 core hyper-threaded processors on it.

The successor will apparently have 4 channel memory, and bring up the rather nice multicore improvements made in Sandy Bridge to it. There are also rumours that all processors in this new platform will be 6 core by default, which is nice.[/quote]Why upgrade at all and just wait forever until computers are not made anymore! Then there will be no need to upgrade EVER?

Read full topic
item.source: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?

item.title: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Radeon, post:12, topic:395974”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=493154.msg3606346#msg3606346 date=1306152296]

Why 12gb of ram? I can’t think of a single purpose for that.
[/quote]Because it’s cheap as balls and i’d be running triple channel. I have 8gb atm, so anything less would be a downgrade.

tbh that makes sense, assuming your current 8gb isn’t ddr3.[/quote]Ye, it isnt.

Read full topic

item.title: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

I know what I’m about to do is sometimes frowned upon, but think about waiting for the successor to that platform (x58). It is pretty much the only platform Intel haven’t upgraded, it is their high end consumer chipset - so all they’ve been doing with it are these ridiculously priced 6 core hyper-threaded processors on it.

The successor will apparently have 4 channel memory, and bring up the rather nice multicore improvements made in Sandy Bridge to it. There are also rumours that all processors in this new platform will be 6 core by default, which is nice.

Read full topic
item.source: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?

item.title: Upgrade in a couple of months, suggestions?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:7, topic:395974”]http://www.overclockers.co.uk/showproduct.php?prodid=MY-294-CS&groupid=701&catid=8&subcat=1389 - RAM
http://www.overclockers.co.uk/showproduct.php?prodid=CP-338-IN&groupid=701&catid=6&subcat=1272 - processor
http://www.overclockers.co.uk/showproduct.php?prodid=MB-395-AS&groupid=701&catid=5&subcat=1692 - mobo

€985.53[/quote]The RAM there is attractive as fuck due to it being 3 sticks rather than 6. Means i can be a bad boy and get 24GB eventually (epenis growth + 500000). The motherboard is quite expensive, i’ll probably get a cheaper one instead. The CPU however looks like something i’ll get.

Thanks for the tips!

Read full topic
